summary.long: Nehemiah is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text:
The words of Nehemiah son of Hakaliah.
In the month of Kislev of the twentieth year, I was in Susa, the citadel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hanani, one of my brothers, came to me with men from Judah. I asked them about the remnant of the Jews, who had survived the captivity and had escaped from it, and about Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said to me, “The survivors from the captivity who are there in the province are in great misery and shame. The wall of Jerusalem is broken down, and its gates have been burned.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When I heard about these things, I sat down and wept. I mourned for days, fasting and praying before the God of Heaven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I said:
Please, Lord, the God of Heaven, the great and awe-inspiring God, who preserves the covenant and faithfulness for those who love him and keep his commands:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Let your ear be attentive and your eyes be open as you hear the prayer of your servant today, which I am now praying before you day and night, concerning the Israelites, who are your servants. I am also confessing the sins of the people of Israel that we committed against you. I and my father’s house have also sinned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We have acted very corruptly against you, and we have not kept the commands, nor the statutes, nor the ordinances that you commanded Moses your servant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Please remember the command you gave to Moses your servant when you said, “If you are unfaithful, I will scatter you among the peoples.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when you return to me and keep my commandments and do them, even if you have been scattered to the end of heaven, from there I will gather them, and I will bring them to the place where I have chosen to make my name dwell.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They are your servants and your people, whom you have redeemed with your great power and your mighty hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Please, my Lord, let your ear be attentive to the prayer of your servant and to the prayers of your servants who are delighted to revere your name. Make your servant successful today, and give him mercy in this man’s presence.
I was cupbearer to the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the month of Nisan in the twentieth year of King Artaxerxes, wine was being served to the king, and I took the wine and gave it to the king. I had never been sad in his presence,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
so the king said to me, “Why do you look sad, since you are not sick? This must be sadness in your heart.”
Then I was very much afraid.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I said to the king, “May the king live forever! Why shouldn’t I look sad when the city, the place of my ancestors’ tombs, lies in ruins, and its gates have been consumed by fire?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the king said to me, “What do you want?”
So I prayed to the God of Heaven,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and I said to the king, “If it seems good to the king, and if you look upon your servant with favor, then send me to Judah, to the city where my ancestors’ tombs are, and let me rebuild it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king said to me, while the queen was sitting next to him, “How long will your journey be and when will you return?”
The king was pleased to send me, so I gave him a definite time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I also said to the king, “If it seems good to the king, please give me letters for the governors of Trans-Euphrates, so that they will grant me safe passage through that province until I come to Judah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: also a letter to Asaph, superintendent of the king’s forest, so that he will give me lumber to lay beams for the gates of the citadel of the temple, for the city wall, and for the house that I will occupy.” The king gave them to me, because the good hand of my God was upon me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I came to the governors of Trans-Euphrates, and I gave them the king’s letters. The king had sent army officers and cavalry with me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Sanballat the Horonite and Tobiah the Ammonite official heard about this, they were very upset that a man had come to seek the welfare of the Israelites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I arrived at Jerusalem and was there for three days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time I got up in the middle of the night with a few men. I had not told anyone what God had placed into my heart to do for Jerusalem. There was no animal with me except the animal on which I was riding.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At night I went out through the Valley Gate and went toward the vicinity of the Jackal Well and the Dung Gate. I began inspecting the walls of Jerusalem, which had been breached, and its gates, which had been consumed by fire.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I crossed over to the Fountain Gate and to the King’s Pool, but there was no place for the animal that I was riding to get through.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I kept going up the valley and inspecting the wall during the night. Then I turned around and went back the same way and came in through the Valley Gate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The officials did not know where I had gone and what I was doing. I had not yet told the Jews—the priests, the nobles, the officials, or the rest of the people who would be doing the work.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I said to them, “You see the very bad situation we are in: Jerusalem lies in ruins, and its gates have been burned. Come, let’s rebuild the wall of Jerusalem, and we will no longer be disgraced.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then I told them that the hand of my God had been good to me, and I also told them the words the king had said to me.
They said, “Let’s get up and rebuild!” Then they encouraged each other for this good work.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Sanballat the Horonite, Tobiah the Ammonite official, and Geshem the Arab heard about it, they ridiculed us and held us in contempt. They said, “What are you doing? Are you rebelling against the king?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I responded to them by saying, “The God of Heaven will make us successful. We, his servants, will rise up and rebuild. But you have no portion or right or heritage in Jerusalem.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The high priest Eliashib and his fellow priests began to work, and they rebuilt the Sheep Gate. They consecrated it and installed its doors. They rebuilt the wall as far as the Tower of the Hundred. They consecrated it as far as the Tower of Hananel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Next to him the men of Jericho rebuilt the wall.
Next to them Zakkur son of Imri rebuilt the wall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The citizens of Sena’ah rebuilt the Fish Gate. They laid its beams and hung its doors with their bolts and their bars.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Next to them Meremoth the son of Uriah, the son of Hakkoz, repaired the wall.
Next to him Meshullam the son of Berekiah, the son of Meshezabel, repaired the wall.
Next to him Zadok son of Ba’ana repaired the wall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Next to him the men of Tekoa repaired the wall. However, their important people would not humble themselves in service to their lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joiada son of Paseah and Meshullam son of Besodeiah repaired the Old Gate. They laid its beams and installed its doors with their bolts and their bars.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Next to them Melatiah the Gibeonite and Jadon the Meronothite repaired the wall with the men from Gibeon and Mizpah, who lived under the jurisdiction of the governor of Trans-Euphrates.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Next to them Uzziel son of Harhaiah, one of the goldsmiths, repaired the wall.
Next to him Hananiah, one of the perfumers, repaired the wall. (However, they abandoned the part of Jerusalem that had been enclosed by the Broad Wall.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Next to him Rephaiah son of Hur, administrator of half of the district of Jerusalem, repaired the wall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Next to him Jedaiah son of Harumaph repaired the wall opposite his house.
Next to him Hattush son of Hashabeneiah repaired the wall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Malkijah son of Harim and Hasshub son of Pahath Moab repaired a second section of the wall, including the Tower of the Ovens.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Next to them Shallum son of Hallohesh, administrator of half of the district of Jerusalem—he and his daughters—repaired the wall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hanun and the inhabitants of Zanoah repaired the Valley Gate. They rebuilt it and installed its doors with their bolts and their bars, and they repaired fifteen hundred feet of the wall as far as the Dung Gate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also, Malkijah son of Recab, administrator of the district of Beth Hakkerem, repaired the Dung Gate. He rebuilt it and installed its doors with their bolts and their bars.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also, Shallun son of Kol Hozeh, administrator of the district of Mizpah, repaired the Fountain Gate. He rebuilt it and roofed it and installed its doors with their bolts and their bars. He also repaired the wall of the Pool of Shelah for the King’s Garden, as far as the steps that go down from the City of David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Beyond him Nehemiah son of Azbuk, administrator of half the district of Beth Zur, repaired the wall up to a point opposite the tombs of David, as far as the Artificial Pool and as far as the House of the Warriors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Beyond him the Levites repaired the wall: Rehum son of Bani and next to him Hashabiah, administrator of half of the district of Keilah, repaired the wall for his district.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Beyond them their relatives repaired the wall: Binnui son of Henadad, administrator of half the district of Keilah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Next to him Ezer son of Jeshua, mayor of Mizpah, repaired a second section of the wall opposite the Ascent of the Armory at the Angle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Beyond him Baruch son of Zabbai zealously repaired a second section of the wall from the Angle to the door of the house of the high priest Eliashib.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Beyond him Meremoth the son of Uriah, the son of Hakkoz, repaired a second section of the wall from the door of Eliashib’s house to the end of Eliashib’s house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And beyond him, the priests, the men of the surrounding area, repaired the wall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Beyond them Benjamin and Hasshub repaired the wall opposite their house.
Beyond them Azariah the son of Ma’aseiah, the son of Ananiah, repaired the wall beside his house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Beyond him Binnui son of Henadad repaired a second section of the wall from the house of Azariah to the Angle, that is, to the Corner.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Palal son of Uzai repaired the wall from opposite the Angle and the tower that projects from the king’s upper house, which belongs to the Courtyard of the Guard.
Beyond him Pedaiah son of Parosh
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the temple servants who were living on the Ophel Hill repaired the wall as far as the Water Gate toward the east and the Projecting Tower.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Beyond them the men of Tekoa repaired a second length of the wall from opposite the large Projecting Tower to the Ophel Wall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Above the Horse Gate the priests repaired the wall. Each man repaired the part opposite his own house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Beyond them Zadok son of Immer repaired the wall opposite his own house.
And beyond him Shemaiah son of Shekaniah, the keeper of the East Gate, repaired the wall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Beyond him Hananiah son of Shelemiah and Hanun, the sixth son of Zalaph, repaired a second section of the wall. After him Meshullam son of Berekiah repaired the wall opposite his chamber.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Beyond him Malkijah, one of the goldsmiths, repaired the wall up to the building of the temple servants and the merchants, opposite the Inspection Gate and to the Upper Room at the Corner.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Between the Upper Room at the Corner and the Sheep Gate, the goldsmiths and the merchants repaired the wall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Sanballat heard that we were rebuilding the wall, it infuriated him, and he became very angry. He ridiculed the Jews
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and said in front of his allies and the army of Samaria, “What are those pathetic Jews doing? Will they restore it by themselves? Will they sacrifice? Will they finish in one day? Will they refurbish the stones that came from the piles of rubble that have been burned?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Tobiah the Ammonite was beside him. He said, “Whatever they are building, if even a fox climbed on it, it would break apart the wall made from their stones.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Listen, O our God, because we are an object of contempt. Turn their ridicule back on their own heads. Hand them over as plunder in a land of captivity.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not cover over their guilt, and may their sin not be blotted out before you, because they have provoked your anger in the presence of the builders.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So we built the wall, and the entire wall was completed, up to half its height, because the people were determined to do it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now when Sanballat, Tobiah, the Arabs, the Ammonites, and the people of Ashdod heard that the repair of Jerusalem’s walls had progressed and the breaches had begun to be filled, they were infuriated.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So all of them conspired to come to attack Jerusalem and to throw it into confusion.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, we prayed to our God, and because of the enemies, we posted a guard over the builders day and night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the people of Judah said, “The strength of those bearing the burden is failing. There is so much rubble. We will not be able to build the wall!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then our adversaries said, “They will not know about it or realize what we are doing, until we come among them and kill them and bring the work to a halt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Jews who lived near them came, they repeatedly told us, “No matter which way you turn, they will be upon us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I stationed people behind the wall at the lowest places, at its open spots. I stationed the people by clans with their swords, spears, and bows.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I looked and got up and said to the nobles, the officials, and the rest of the people, “Do not be afraid of them. Remember the Lord, who is great and fearsome. So fight for your brothers, your sons and your daughters, your wives, and your homes.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When our enemies heard that their plan was known to us and that God had frustrated their strategy, all of us returned to the wall, each man to his own work.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From that day on, half of the young men who were serving under me were doing the work, and half of them were holding shields, spears, and bows and wearing armor. The officers were stationed behind the whole house of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people who were building the wall and those who were carrying the materials for building were doing their work with one hand, while the other hand held a weapon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As they built, the builders were armed, each man with his sword on his hip. The man who sounded the ram’s horn was next to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I said to the nobles, the officials, and the rest of the people, “There is a lot of work, and it is spread out, and we are separated along the wall—all the people are far away from each other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Wherever you hear the sound of the ram’s horn, gather with us at that spot. Our God will fight for us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So we continued to work with half of the people holding spears, from the crack of dawn until the stars came out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also at that time I said to the people, “Let every man and his servant spend the night in Jerusalem. They will serve as a guard for us at night, and in the daytime they will work.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Neither I nor my brothers nor my servants nor the men of the guard who were behind me—none of us took off our clothes. Each man had his weapon in his hand, even when getting a drink of water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now there was a great outcry by the people and their wives against their fellow Jews.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were those who were saying, “We and our sons and our daughters are many! We need to acquire grain so that we can eat and stay alive.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were others who were saying, “We are mortgaging our fields, vineyards, and houses so that we can acquire grain during the famine.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were others who were saying, “We borrowed money to pay the royal tax on our fields and vineyards.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Although our flesh is the same as the flesh of our countrymen, and our children are as good as their children, we must subject our sons and our daughters to slavery. Some of our daughters are already enslaved, but we have no power to prevent it, since our fields and vineyards belong to others.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It infuriated me when I heard their outcry and these words.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My heart guided me, and I accused the nobles and the officials. I said to them, “Each of you is loaning money at interest to his brother Israelite.”
I called for a large meeting to deal with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I said to them, “As much as possible, we have bought back our fellow Judeans who have been sold to the Gentiles, and yet, you sell your countrymen so that they can be resold to us!” They were silent and could not find a word to say.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I said, “What you are doing is not good. Shouldn’t you walk in the fear of our God because of the ridicule from the Gentiles, who are our enemies?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In addition, I, my brothers, and my servants are lending them money and grain. I urge you. Let’s abandon the practice of charging this interest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I urge you. Today give them back their fields, their vineyards, their olive trees, their homes, and the money they were charged as interest, also the grain, the new wine, and the olive oil for which you have been charging them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They said, “We will give it back, and we will not seek anything else from them. In this way we will do what you say.”
So I called the priests and made them swear to act according to this promise.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I also shook out the folds of my garment and said, “In this way may God shake out from his home and from his property every man who does not keep this promise. May he be shaken out and emptied in this way.”
The entire assembly said, “Amen,” and they praised the Lord. Then the people kept this promise.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In addition, from the day that he appointed me to be the governor of the land of Judah, from the twentieth year to the thirty-second year of King Artaxerxes—twelve years—I and my brothers did not eat the governor’s food allowance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, the previous governors who served before me had placed a heavy burden on the people. They took food and wine from them—valued at forty silver shekels. Even the lower officials lorded over the people. But because of the fear of God, I did not do this.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In addition, I dedicated myself to the work on this wall (although we had acquired no land), and all of my servants were gathered there for the work.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moreover, at my table there were one hundred fifty Judeans and officials, and others who came to us from the nations around us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whatever was prepared for each day was at my expense: one ox, six choice sheep, and some birds, and every ten days plenty of every kind of wine. But even with this, I still did not requisition the governor’s food allowance, because the required service weighed heavily on this people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Remember me, my God, for good, considering all that I have done for this people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When it was reported to Sanballat, Tobiah, Geshem the Arab, and the rest of our enemies that I had rebuilt the wall and there was no breach left in it (although at that time I had not installed doors in the gates),
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sanballat and Geshem sent a message to me: “Come, let’s meet together in Kephirim in the Plain of Ono.” (However, they were planning to harm me.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I sent messengers to them, saying, “I am working on an important project, and I am not able to come down. Why should the project stop while I leave it and come down to you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They sent messages like this to me four times, and I answered them that same way each time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Sanballat sent his servant to me with a message like this for a fifth time, with an open letter in his hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In it was written, “It is rumored among the nations, and Gashmu also says that you and the Jews are planning to rebel. This is the reason you are building the wall. According to these reports, you will be their king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You have also set up prophets to make a proclamation about you in Jerusalem: ‘A king is in Judah.’ Now reports like these will be heard by the king. So now come, let us consult with one another.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I sent a reply to him: “These things that you are saying have not been done, since you are simply making them up.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So all of them were trying to intimidate us, thinking, “Their hands will grow weary of the work, and it will not be finished.”
So now, strengthen my hands!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I came to the house of Shemaiah the son of Delaiah, the son of Mehetabel. (He was restricted.) He said, “Let’s meet at the house of God in the middle of the temple. Let’s close the doors of the temple, since they are coming to kill you—at night they are coming to kill you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I said, “Should a man like me flee? Should someone like me go to the temple to save my life? I won’t go!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I realized that God had not sent him, but he had spoken the prophecy against me because Tobiah and Sanballat had hired him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For this purpose he was hired—to make me afraid so that I would do this and sin. Then they would have given me a bad reputation, so that they could discredit me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My God, remember Tobiah and Sanballat in light of these actions and also the prophetess Noadiah and the rest of the prophets who were trying to intimidate me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the wall was finished in fifty-two days, on the twenty-fifth of Elul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As all our enemies heard about it, all the nations that were around us became afraid and lost their confidence. They knew that this work had been accomplished by our God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Furthermore, in those days the nobles of Judah were sending many letters to Tobiah, and letters from Tobiah were coming to them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because many in Judah were bound to him by oath because he was the son-in-law of Shekaniah son of Arah, and his son Jehohanan had married the daughter of Meshullam son of Berekiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They were also talking about his good deeds in my presence, and they were reporting my words to him. Tobiah was sending letters to try to intimidate me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the wall had been built and I had installed the doors, and when the gatekeepers, the singers, and the Levites had been appointed,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I placed my brother Hanani along with Hananiah, the commander of the citadel, in charge of Jerusalem, because he was a trustworthy man and feared God more than many.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I said to them, “The gates of Jerusalem should not be left open until the heat of the day, but while the guards are still on duty, they are to shut the doors and secure them. Appoint guards from the residents of Jerusalem, some at their guard posts and some in front of their houses.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the city was wide open and spacious, but there were few people in it, and no houses were being built.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So my God placed into my heart a plan to gather the nobles, the officials, and the people so they could be enrolled by genealogy. I found the genealogical record of those who were the first to come up from Babylon. I found this written in it:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the people of the province who went up from the captivity of the exiles, whom King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon had exiled. They returned to Jerusalem and to Judah, each man to his city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These were the people who came with Zerubbabel, Jeshua, Nehemiah, Azariah, Ra’amiah, Nahamani, Mordecai, Bilshan, Mispereth, Bigvai, Nehum, and Ba’anah.
This was the number of men from the people of Israel:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the male descendants of Parosh: 2,172
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the male descendants of Shephatiah: 372
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the male descendants of Arah: 652
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the male descendants of Pahath Moab through the descendants of Jeshua and Joab: 2,818
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the male descendants of Elam: 1,254
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the male descendants of Zattu: 845
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the male descendants of Zakkai: 760
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the male descendants of Binnui: 648
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the male descendants of Bebai: 628
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the male descendants of Azgad: 2,322
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the male descendants of Adonikam: 667
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the male descendants of Bigvai: 2,067
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the male descendants of Adin: 655
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the male descendants of Ater through Hezekiah: 98
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the male descendants of Hashum: 328
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the male descendants of Bezai: 324
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the male descendants of Hariph: 112
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The following are the people who came up from Tel Melah, Tel Harsha, Kerub, Addon, and Immer. They were not to prove their ancestry or descent—whether they were from Israel:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the descendants of Delaiah, the descendants of Tobiah, the descendants of Nekoda: 642,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and from the priests: the descendants of Habaiah, the descendants of Hakkoz, the descendants of Barzillai, that is, from a man who married one of the daughters of Barzillai the Gileadite and so was called by their name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These people searched for their genealogical records, but they could not find them, so they were disqualified from the priesthood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The governor told them that they should not eat from the most holy sacrifices until a priest would arise who could serve with Urim and Thummim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The entire assembly together totaled 42,360,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: not counting their male slaves and their female slaves, who numbered 7,337. They also had 245 male and female singers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They had 736 horses, 245 mules,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: 435 camels, and 6,720 donkeys.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Some of the heads of the families gave support for the work.
The governor gave to the treasury:
    gold darics: 1,000
    bowls: 50
    garments for the priests: 530.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Some of the heads of the families gave this to the treasury for the work:
    gold darics: 20,000
    silver minas: 2,200.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What the rest of the people gave was this:
    gold darics: 20,000
    silver minas: 2,000
    and garments for the priests: 67.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests, the Levites, the gatekeepers, the singers, some of the people, and the temple servants, that is, all Israel, settled in their cities.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the seventh month came and the Israelites were in their cities, all the people gathered together at the public square that is in front of the Water Gate. They told Ezra the scribe to bring the Book of the Law of Moses, which the Lord had commanded Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So on the first day of the seventh month, Ezra the priest brought the Law before the congregation, both men and women and all who were able to understand what they heard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From dawn until midday in front of the public square in front of the Water Gate, he read from the scroll, while facing the men, the women, and those who could understand. All the people listened attentively to the Book of the Law.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ezra the scribe stood on a wooden platform that was made for the occasion. Beside him stood Mattithiah, Shema, Anaiah, Uriah, Hilkiah, and Ma’aseiah on his right, and on his left were Pedaiah, Mishael, Malkijah, Hashum, Hashbaddanah, Zechariah, and Meshullam.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people could see Ezra as he opened the scroll, because he was elevated above all the people. As he opened the scroll, all the people stood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Ezra blessed the Lord, the great God, and all the people answered, “Amen! Amen!” while they lifted up their hands and then knelt and bowed down with their faces to the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeshua and Bani and Sherebiah, Jamin, Akkub, Shabbethai, Hodiah, Ma’aseiah, Kelita, Azariah, Jozabad, Hanan, Pelaiah, and the rest of the Levites helped the people understand the Law, while the people remained standing in their places.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they read from the Book of the Law of God clearly and interpreted it, and the people understood what was read.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Nehemiah the governor, Ezra the priest and scribe, and the Levites, who helped the people understand, said to all the people, “Today is holy to the Lord your God. Do not mourn or cry!” because all the people were crying as they heard the words of the Law.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nehemiah said to them, “Go, eat rich food and drink sweet drinks and send portions to those who have nothing prepared, because today is holy to our Lord. Do not grieve, because the joy of the Lord is your strength.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Levites silenced all the people, saying, “Hush! Today is holy. Do not grieve.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people went to eat and drink and to send portions to others and to celebrate with great joy, because they understood the words that had been made known to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now on the second day, the heads of the families of all the people, the priests, and the Levites were gathered around Ezra the scribe to study the words of the Law.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They found written in the Law, which the Lord had commanded by the hand of Moses, that the Israelites should dwell in temporary shelters during the festival of the seventh month,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and that they should proclaim this and make this announcement in all their cities and in Jerusalem: “Go out to the mountains and bring branches from olive trees, wild olive trees, myrtle bushes, date palms, and leafy trees to make shelters, as it is written.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the people went out and brought branches and made shelters for themselves. Each man made a shelter on his roof. They also made shelters in their courtyards, in the courtyards of the house of God, in the square by the Water Gate, and in the square by the Ephraim Gate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The entire congregation that had returned from the captivity made shelters and stayed in the shelters. From the days of Joshua son of Nun until that day, the Israelites had not celebrated in this way, because there was very great joy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ezra also read from the Book of the Law of God every day of the festival, from the first day to the last day. They celebrated the festival for seven days, and on the eighth day they held an assembly according to the ordinance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the twenty-fourth day of this same month, the Israelites gathered together. They were fasting and wearing sackcloth, and they had dirt on their faces.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Those of Israelite descent had separated themselves from all foreigners. They stood and confessed their sins and the guilt of their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They stood up in their place and read from the Book of the Law of the Lord their God for a quarter of the day, and for another quarter they confessed their sins and worshipped the Lord their God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jeshua and Bani, Kadmiel, Shebaniah, Bunni, Sherebiah, Bani, and Kenani stood on the stairs for the Levites and cried out in a loud voice to the Lord their God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Levites Jeshua and Kadmiel, Bani, Hashabneiah, Sherebiah, Hodiah, Shebaniah, and Pethahiah said,
“Stand up! Bless the Lord your God,
        who is from eternity to eternity.
May they bless your glorious Name,
        which is more exalted than all other blessing and praise.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You are the Lord—you alone.
        You made the heavens—
        the highest heavens and their entire army,
        the earth and everything that is on it,
        the seas and all that is in them.
        You sustain life in all of them,
        and the army of heaven worships you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You are the Lord, the God who chose Abram.
        You brought him from Ur of the Chaldeans,
        and you gave him the name Abraham.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You found his heart to be faithful before you.
        You made the covenant with him
        to give to his descendants the land of the Canaanites,
        the Hittites, the Amorites and the Perizzites,
        and the Jebusites and the Girgashites.
        You kept your word, because you are righteous.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You saw the oppression of our ancestors in Egypt.
        You heard their cry at the Red Sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You performed signs and wonders against Pharaoh,
        against all his officials,
        and against all the people of his land,
        because you knew that they were acting arrogantly against Israel.
        You made a name for yourself, as it remains to this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You split the sea in front of them,
        and they passed through the middle of it on dry ground.
        You threw their pursuers into the depths like a stone into mighty waters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
With a pillar of cloud you led them by day
        and with a pillar of fire by night,
        which lit up for them the way they were to travel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You came down on Mount Sinai and spoke with them from heaven.
        You gave them upright judgments and true laws,
        good statutes and commandments.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You made known to them your holy Sabbath.
        You gave them commandments, statutes,
        and the Law, by the hand of your servant Moses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You gave them bread from heaven for their hunger,
        and you made water come out of a rock for their thirst.
        Then you told them to go and take possession of the land
        that you swore to give them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But they and our ancestors acted arrogantly.
        They became stiff-necked and would not listen to your commands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So they refused to listen,
        and they did not remember your wonders that you did for them.
        They became stiff-necked and appointed a leader
        in order to return to their slavery in Egypt.
        But you are a God who is forgiving, merciful, and compassionate,
        slow to anger, abounding in mercy.
        So you did not abandon them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
However, they made a cast metal calf for themselves and said,
        “This is your god who brought you up from Egypt,”
        and they committed great blasphemies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But in your abundant compassion, you did not abandon them in the wilderness.
        By day the pillar of cloud did not depart from above them
        or stop leading them on their way.
        By night the pillar of fire did not stop lighting the way that they should go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You gave them your good Spirit to give them insight.
        So you did not withhold your manna from their mouth,
        and you gave them water for their thirst.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You sustained them for forty years in the wilderness.
        They did not lack anything.
        Their clothing did not wear out,
        and their feet did not swell.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You gave them kingdoms and peoples,
and you divided their whole territory among them.
They took possession of the land of Sihon, the land of the king of Heshbon,
and also the land of Og, the king of Bashan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You made their children as numerous as the stars of heaven.
You brought them to the land that you had told their ancestors to enter and possess.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Their children came and possessed the land,
and you subdued the Canaanite inhabitants of the land before them.
You gave their kings and the peoples of the land into their hand
to do with them as they pleased.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They captured fortified cities and fertile land.
They possessed houses full of all kinds of good things,
hewn cisterns, vineyards, olive orchards,
and fruit trees in abundance.
They ate and were satisfied.
They became fat and delighted in your great goodness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But they rebelled and revolted against you and rejected your Law.
They killed your prophets, who had testified against them
so that they would return to you.
They also committed great blasphemies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So you delivered them into the hand of their oppressors,
who made them suffer.
But when they cried to you at the time of their distress,
you heard from heaven,
and according to your great compassion, you gave them deliverers,
who saved them from the hand of their oppressors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
However, as soon as they had rest, they returned to doing evil before you.
So you abandoned them into the hand of their enemies,
and they ruled over them.
Then they turned and cried out to you.
You heard from heaven,
and you rescued them many times, according to your great compassion.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You testified against them to lead them back to your law,
but they acted arrogantly and did not listen to your commands.
They sinned against your judgments
by which a man will live when he obeys them.
They turned their backs on you, became stiff-necked, and would not listen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You were patient with them for many years,
and you testified against them by your Spirit through your prophets.
But they would not listen,
so you gave them into the hand of the peoples of the lands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Nevertheless, in your great compassion you did not put an end to them.
You did not abandon them,
because you are a gracious and compassionate God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So now, you our God, the great, mighty, and awe-inspiring God,
who keeps the covenant of mercy,
do not regard as trivial all the hardships that have found us,
our kings, our officials, our priests, our prophets,
our ancestors, and all your people,
from the days of the kings of Assyria to this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You are righteous in regard to everything that has come upon us,
because you have acted faithfully, but we have acted wickedly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Our kings, our officials, our priests, and our ancestors did not follow your law.
They did not pay attention to your commands
or to your testimony that you gave against them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Although they were in their own kingdom,
and they were enjoying your great goodness that you gave to them,
and they were enjoying the spacious and fertile land
that you placed before them,
they still did not serve you,
and they did not repent of their evil deeds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As a result, we are slaves today.
We are slaves in the land that you gave to our ancestors
so that they could eat its fruit and its good things.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It is yielding abundant produce to kings
whom you placed over us because of our sins,
and they are ruling our bodies and our livestock as they please,
while we are in great distress.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So in all this we are making a solemn agreement and putting it in writing and attaching the seals of our officials, Levites, and priests.
These were the men who placed their seals on it:
Nehemiah the governor, the son of Hakaliah,
Zedekiah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Seraiah, Azariah, Jeremiah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pashhur, Amariah, Malkijah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hattush, Shebaniah, Malluk,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Harim, Meremoth, Obadiah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Daniel, Ginnethon, Baruch,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meshullam, Abijah, Mijamin,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Ma’aziah, Bilgai, Shemaiah.
These are the priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Levites were:
Jeshua son of Azaniah, Binnui from the sons of Henadad, and Kadmiel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Their relatives were Shebaniah, Hodiah, Kelita, Pelaiah, Hanan,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Mica, Rehob, Hashabiah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zakkur, Sherebiah, Shebaniah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hodiah, Bani, and Beninu.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The heads of the people were:
Parosh, Pahath Moab, Elam, Zattu, Bani,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Bunni, Azgad, Bebai,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Adonijah, Bigvai, Adin,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ater, Hezekiah, Azzur,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hodiah, Hashum, Bezai,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hariph, Anathoth, Nebai,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Magpiash, Meshullam, Hezir,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meshezabel, Zadok, Jaddua,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pelatiah, Hanan, Anaiah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hoshea, Hananiah, Hasshub,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hallohesh, Pilha, Shobek,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rehum, Hashabnah, Ma’aseiah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and Ahiah, Hanan, Anan,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Malluk, Harim, Ba’anah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the rest of the people, the priests, the Levites, the gatekeepers, the singers, the temple servants, and every person who had separated himself from the peoples of the lands for the sake of the Law of God, with their wives, their sons, and their daughters—all the people who have knowledge and understanding—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: are making a commitment with their brothers, that is, with the important people, and they are placing themselves under a curse and under an oath to walk in the Law of God that was given through Moses the servant of God, an oath to keep the law and to obey all the commands of the Lord our God and his judgments and his statutes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
We promise to keep these points:
We will not give our daughters in marriage to the peoples of the land, and we will not take their daughters for marriage to our sons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
We will not buy anything from the peoples of the land who are bringing goods and all kinds of grain to sell on the Sabbath day or on a holy day.
We will leave the land fallow during the seventh year, and we will forgive every loan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We will each assume the responsibility to keep the commands to give a third of a shekel per year for the service of the house of our God,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: for the Bread of the Presence, for the regular daily grain offerings, the continual burnt offerings, the Sabbath offerings, the New Moon offerings, for the appointed festivals and holy offerings, and for sin offerings to atone for Israel, and for all the work of the house of our God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We—the priests, the Levites, and the people—have cast lots to determine our turns for each fathers’ house to bring the wood offering to the house of our God, at the appointed times each year, to be burned upon the altar of the Lord our God, as it is written in the Law.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We pledge to bring the firstfruits of our land and the firstfruits of every kind of fruit tree to the house of our God for ourselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We also will bring the firstborn of our sons and our animals, as is written in the Law, and we will bring the firstborn of our cattle and flocks to the house of our God for the priests who serve in the house of our God,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and we will bring the first of our dough and our contributions and the fruit of every tree. We will bring new wine and olive oil to the priests, to the storerooms of the house of our God, and we will bring the tithe from our land to the Levites. It is the Levites who collect the tithes in all the cities where we work.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A priest, a descendant of Aaron, will be with the Levites when the Levites collect the tithes. The Levites will bring a tenth of the tithes up to the house of our God, to the chambers of the treasury,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because the Israelites and the sons of Levi are to bring the contribution from the grain, the new wine, and the olive oil to the storerooms where the vessels of the sanctuary are kept, where the priests, the gatekeepers, and the singers serve.
In this way we will not abandon the house of our God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people’s officials lived in Jerusalem, and the rest of the people cast lots to choose one out of every ten to live in Jerusalem, the holy city, while the other nine remained in their own cities.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people blessed all those who volunteered to live in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is a listing of the heads of the province who lived in Jerusalem. (Meanwhile, in the cities of Judah, each man lived on his own property, including laymen from Israel, the priests, the Levites, the temple servants, and the descendants of Solomon’s servants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But some of the descendants of Judah and some of the descendants of Benjamin also lived in Jerusalem.)
From the descendants of Judah:
        Athaiah the son of Uzziah, the son of Zechariah, the son of Amariah, the son of Shephatiah, the son of Mahalalel, from the descendants of Perez.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ma’aseiah the son of Baruch, the son of Kol Kozeh, the son of Hazaiah, the son of Adaiah, the son of Joiarib, the son of Zechariah, the son of the Shilonite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the descendants of Perez who dwelt in Jerusalem were 468 able-bodied men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These are the descendants of Benjamin:
        Sallu the son of Meshullam, the son of Joed, the son of Pedaiah, the son of Kolaiah, the son of Ma’aseiah, the son of Ithiel, the son of Jeshaiah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and after him Gabbai and Sallai: 928 in all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joel son of Zikri was their overseer, and Judah son of Hassenuah was second in command over the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
From the priests:
        Jedaiah the son of Joiarib, Jakin,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Seraiah the son of Hilkiah, the son of Meshullam, the son of Zadok, the son of Meraioth, the son of Ahitub, ruler of the house of God,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and their relatives who were doing the work of the house: 822.
        Also Adaiah the son of Jeroham, the son of Pelaliah, the son of Amzi, the son of Zechariah, the son of Pashhur, the son of Malkijah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and his relatives, heads of families: 242.
        Also Amashsai the son of Azarel, the son of Ahzai, the son of Meshillemoth, the son of Immer,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and their relatives, very capable men: 128.
        Their overseer was Zabdiel son of Haggedolim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
From the Levites:
        Shemaiah, who was the son of Hasshub, the son of Azrikam, the son of Hashabiah, the son of Bunni.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also Shabbethai and Jozabad, who were supervisors over the outside work of the house of God. They were from the heads of the Levites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Also Mattaniah, who was the son of Mica, the son of Zabdi, the son of Asaph, leader of the praise and thanksgiving for the prayer.
        Also Bakbukiah, second in rank among his relatives, and Abda the son of Shammua, the son of Galal, the son of Jeduthun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the Levites in the holy city numbered 284.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These are the gatekeepers:
        Akkub, Talmon, and their relatives who guarded the gates numbered 172.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of Israel, the priests, and the Levites were in all the cities of Judah, each man in his own inheritance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The temple servants were dwelling in the Ophel, and Ziha and Gishpa were supervisors over the temple servants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The overseer of the Levites in Jerusalem was Uzzi the son of Bani, the son of Hashabiah, the son of Mattaniah, the son of Mica, from the descendants of Asaph, who were the singers for the service of the house of God,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: for they were under a royal command—an order concerning the singers’ daily duty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pethahiah son of Meshezabel, from the descendants of Zerah the son of Judah, served as the hand of the king for every matter concerning the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is the information about the villages with their fields:
Some of the descendants of Judah lived in Kiriath Arba and its settlements, in Dibon and its settlements, and in Jekabze’el and its settlements,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and in Jeshua, in Moladah, and in Beth Pelet,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and in Hazar Shual, and in Beersheba and its settlements,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and in Ziklag, and in Mekonah and in its settlements,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and in En Rimmon, and in Zorah, and in Jarmuth,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zanoah and Adullam and their villages, Lachish and its fields, and Azekah and its settlements. So they settled from Beersheba to the Hinnom Valley.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some of the descendants of Benjamin were from Geba, Mikmash, Aijah, and Bethel and its settlements,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Anathoth, Nob, Ananiah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hazor, Ramah, Gittaim,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hadid, Zeboim, Neballat,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Lod, and Ono, and the Valley of the Craftsmen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some of the Levite divisions of Judah were assigned to Benjamin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These are the priests and the Levites who came up with Zerubbabel son of Shealtiel and with Jeshua:
        Seraiah, Jeremiah, Ezra,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Amariah, Malluk, Hattush,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shekaniah, Rehum, Meremoth,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Iddo, Ginnethoi, Abijah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Mijamin, Ma’adiah, Bilgah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shemaiah, and Joiarib, Jedaiah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Sallu, Amok, Hilkiah, and Jedaiah.
        These were the heads of the priests and their relatives in the days of Jeshua.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These are the Levites:
        Jeshua, Binnui, Kadmiel, Sherebiah, Judah,
        Mattaniah (he and his relatives were in charge of songs of thanksgiving),
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and Bakbukiah and Unni (their relatives were stationed opposite them for the services).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Now Jeshua was the father of Joiakim,
        and Joiakim was the father of Eliashib,
        and Eliashib was the father of Joiada,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and Joiada was the father of Jonathan,
        and Jonathan was the father of Jaddua.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Now in the days of Joiakim, the priests who were the heads of the families were as follows:
        the head of Seraiah’s family was Meraiah
        of Jeremiah’s: Hananiah
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
of Ezra’s: Meshullam
        of Amariah’s: Jehohanan
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
of Malluk’s: Jonathan
        of Shebaniah’s: Joseph
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
of Harim’s: Adna
        of Meraioth’s: Helkai
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
of Iddo’s: Zechariah
        of Ginnethon’s: Meshullam
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
of Abijah’s: Zikri
        of Miniamin’s, of Moadiah’s: Piltai
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
of Bilgah’s: Shammua
        of Shemaiah’s: Jehonathan
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and of Joiarib’s: Mattenai
        of Jedaiah’s: Uzzi
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
of Sallai’s: Kallai
        of Amok’s: Eber
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
of Hilkiah’s: Hashabiah
        of Jedaiah’s: Nethanel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the days of Eliashib, Joiada, and Johanan, and Jaddua, the Levites were recorded by the heads of families, as were the priests, until the reign of Darius the Persian.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The descendants of Levi who were heads of families were recorded in the book of the chronicles, down to the days of Johanan son of Eliashib.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The heads of the Levites were as follows:
Hashabiah, Sherebiah, and Jeshua son of Kadmiel and his relatives, who stood opposite them to praise and to give thanks according to the command of David the man of God, one division corresponding to another.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Mattaniah and Bakbukiah, Obadiah, Meshullam, Talmon, and Akkub were gatekeepers standing guard at the storerooms at the gates.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These men served in the days of Joiakim the son of Jeshua, the son of Jozadak, and in the days of Nehemiah the governor, and Ezra the priest, the scribe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now for the dedication of the wall of Jerusalem, the Levites had been invited from all their places, in order to bring them to Jerusalem to celebrate the joyful dedication with both thanksgiving hymns and with songs using cymbals, harps, and lyres.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The singers had been gathered both from the district around Jerusalem and from the villages of the Netophathites,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: from Beth Gilgal, and from the countryside of Geba and Azmaveth, because the singers had built villages for themselves around Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests and the Levites purified themselves, and they purified the people, the gates, and the wall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I brought the officers of Judah up onto the wall and appointed two large thanksgiving choirs and two groups for the procession.
One group proceeded south on top of the west wall toward the Dung Gate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Behind them went Hoshaiah and half of the officers of Judah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: also Azariah, Ezra, and Meshullam,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Judah and Benjamin, and Shemaiah and Jeremiah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: as well as some of the priests with trumpets, namely, Zechariah the son of Jonathan, the son of Shemaiah, the son of Mattaniah, the son of Micaiah, the son of Zakkur, the son of Asaph,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and his relatives Shemaiah, Azarel, Milalai, Gilalai, Ma’ai, Nethanel, and Judah, and Hanani with the musical instruments of David the man of God. Ezra the scribe led them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From the Fountain Gate they went directly up the steps to the City of David, by the ascent to the wall which was above David’s house and over the Water Gate on the east.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The second thanksgiving choir was assigned to go in the opposite direction. Both I and half of the people were behind it on top of the wall. They went over the Tower of the Ovens to the Broad Wall,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and over the Ephraim Gate (that is, over the Old Gate), and over the Fish Gate and the Tower of Hananel and the Tower of the Hundred, and up to the Sheep Gate, and they stood at the Guard’s Gate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The two thanksgiving choirs stood in the house of God, as did I and half of the officials with me,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: as well as the priests: Eliakim, Ma’aseiah, Miniamin, Mikaiah, Elioenai, Zechariah, and Hananiah with trumpets,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and Ma’aseiah, Shemaiah, Eleazar, Uzzi, Jehohanan, and Malkijah, and Elam, and Ezer. Then the singers sang with Jezrahiah as their leader.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That day they offered great sacrifices and rejoiced because God had given them great joy. The women and children also rejoiced. The joy of Jerusalem was heard a long way away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That day men were appointed as supervisors over the storerooms, the contributions, the firstfruits, and the tithes, in order to gather the portions required by the Law for the priests and the Levites from the fields of the towns, because Judah rejoiced over the priests and Levites who carried out their duties.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They and the singers and the gatekeepers continued the service of their God and the service of purification, according to the command of David and his son Solomon,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because formerly in the days of David and Asaph, Asaph was the head of the singers and of songs of praise and thanksgiving to God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the days of Zerubbabel and in the days of Nehemiah, all Israel continued to give the required portions for the singers and the gatekeepers daily. They would set apart that portion which was for the Levites, and the Levites would set apart that portion which was for the descendants of Aaron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On that day, when the Book of Moses was being read in the hearing of the people, it was found written in it that no Ammonite or Moabite may ever come into the assembled congregation of God,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because they had not met the Israelites with food and water but had hired Balaam against them to curse them. However, our God had turned the curse into a blessing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As the people heard the Law, they separated everyone of mixed foreign descent from Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But before this, the priest Eliashib, who had been put in charge of the storerooms of the house of our God, and who was related to Tobiah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
had provided a large storeroom for him.
Previously they had been putting the offerings, the incense, and the vessels, as well as the tithes of grain, new wine, and olive oil there. This had been done according to the command concerning the Levites, the singers, the gatekeepers, and the contributions for the priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when all this was happening, I was not in Jerusalem, because in the thirty-second year of King Artaxerxes of Babylon, I had gone to the king. Then sometime later, I asked the king for permission to return,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and I came back to Jerusalem. Then I found out about the evil thing that Eliashib had done for Tobiah by providing a room for him in the courtyards of the house of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This was very offensive to me, so I threw all of Tobiah’s household property out of the storeroom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I gave orders to purify the storerooms, and I restored the articles of the house of God, the offerings, and the incense.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I learned that the portions for the Levites had not been distributed and that the Levites and singers who performed the work of God’s house all had gone back to their own fields.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I accused the officials and said, “Why has the house of God been abandoned?” So I gathered them and stationed them at their places.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all Judah brought the tithes of grain and new wine and olive oil to the storerooms.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I appointed treasurers in charge of the storerooms: the priest Shelemiah, the scribe Zadok, Pedaiah from the Levites, and as their assistant, Hanan the son of Zakkur, the son of Mattaniah, because they were considered to be trustworthy. It was their responsibility to distribute the portions to their relatives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Remember me, my God, because of this, and do not wipe away my faithful deeds, which I have done for the sake of the house of my God and for the sake of its services.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In those days I saw in Judah some people who were treading winepresses on the Sabbath and bringing heaps of grain and loading them on donkeys, and also wine, grapes, and figs and all kinds of loads, and then bringing them to Jerusalem on the Sabbath. So I warned them on the day when they were selling food.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moreover, some people from Tyre lived in the city. They were bringing fish and all kinds of merchandise and selling it on the Sabbath to the Jews—even in Jerusalem!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I accused the Judean nobles and said to them, “What is this evil thing that you are doing, by which you are profaning the Sabbath day?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Didn’t your ancestors do this, and as a result our God brought all this calamity upon us and upon this city? You are adding more to his wrath by profaning the Sabbath.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As it began to grow dark within the gates of Jerusalem before the beginning of the Sabbath, I gave orders to close the doors and not to open them until after the Sabbath. I also stationed some of my servants at the gates to ensure that no load would come in on the Sabbath day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Once or twice the merchants and those who sell all kinds of merchandise spent the night outside of Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, I warned them and said to them, “Why are you spending the night next to the wall? If you do this again, I will use force against you.” From that time onward they did not come on the Sabbath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then I told the Levites that they should purify themselves and come to guard the gates in order to sanctify the Sabbath day.
Remember this also in my favor, my God, and spare me according to your great faithfulness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also in those days I saw the Judeans who had married women from Ashdod, Ammon, and Moab.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Half of their children spoke the dialect of Ashdod or the language of other peoples and were not able to understand how to speak Judean.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I accused them and cursed them. I beat some of the men and pulled out their hair. Then I made them take an oath by God: “May God punish us if we give our daughters to their sons or if we take some of their daughters for our sons or for ourselves.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I said, “Wasn’t it because of these foreign wives that King Solomon of Israel sinned, although there was no king like him among the many nations? He was loved by his God, and God placed him as king over all Israel. Yet foreign wives made even him sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Should we listen to you and be led to do all this great evil, so that we end up being unfaithful to our God by marrying foreign women?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One of the sons of Joiada, the son of Eliashib, the high priest, was the son-in-law of Sanballat the Horonite. So I chased him away from me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Remember them, my God, because of their defiling of the priesthood and because of the covenant of the priesthood and the Levites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I purified them of everything foreign, and I established duties for the priests and the Levites—each man had his own work.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I also provided wood for the offerings at the appropriate times and for the offerings of the firstfruits.
Remember me, my God, for good.
verses.speaker: Narrator
